commits.message:
refactor(processor): extract common methods into helper

With this change a helper class will be introduced, which offers a
static method `forwardRequests` that maps an ODataRequest into an entity
request and sends it to the related entity verticles. Before, this logic
was included in most of the handlers.

Co-authored-by: Pascal Krause <pascal.krause@sap.com>

commits.message:
refactor: made the ClassPathScanner non-blocking

Followed by the the DeployableScanner and the HookScanner, resulting in unblocking NeonBeeModule, the EntityModelManager and the NeonBee bootstrap overall.

Nicer implementation of closing the NeonBeeModule's associated SelfFirstClassLoader and fixing a bug in the HookScanner, which previously ignored hooks in the manifest file.

commits.message:
refactor: move error handler configuration to ServerConfig class

Before this change the JsonObject passed to the ServerVerticle was used to read the configuration for the custom error template to use. With this change the JsonObject was replaced by the ServerConfig object. In addition to a custom errorHandlerClassName a new errorHandlerTemplate property was added, which can be used to just specify a different (HTML) template to use in the DefaultErrorHandler.

Switched to promisified interfaces in FileSystemHelper. Increased the code coverage error threshold to 80% instead of 81%, as the violation plugin did fail at 81.0% eventhough the failIfLessThanThresholdError was set.
commits.commitSubject: move error handler configuration to ServerConfig class

commits.message:
feat: allow multiple MANIFST.MF files when parsing NeonBee-Module

Normally there is exactly one MANIFEST.MF on the classpath, because when
parsing a NeonBee-Module a complete isolated classloader is used. But at
the end it doesn't matter how many MANIFEST.MF files are existing as
long as there is only one that contains the NeonBee-Module attributes.
Therefore this change adds more tolerance to the NeonBee-Module
validation.

This also helps in case that a third party library (like Dynatrace)
manipulates the classpath of every URLClassloader by adding own JARs.
commits.commitSubject: allow multiple MANIFST.MF files when parsing NeonBee-Module

commits.message:
fix: example for ServerVerticle (ServerConfig)

Creating ServerConfig from file uses generic converter classes generated
by Vert.x code generator. In case that these converters need to convert
a String into an Enum, it simply uses Enum.valueOf(..). This requires
that the Enum values represented by the Strings are upper case.

It also fixes the wrong endpoint types.

commits.message:
refactor!: move files to prepare upcoming NeonBeeConfig change

Moving and modifying the same file in a commit, could lead to the
situation that git diff [1] does not detect the move. This could be
prevented by splitting movement and modification into two separate
commits.

This commit won't build and is only valid in combination with its
following partner commit, which represents the modification part.

[1] https://git-scm.com/docs/git-diff#Documentation/git-diff.txt---find-renamesltngt

commits.

following partner commit, which represents the modification part.

commits.message:
feat: make launcher options configurable via env

For deployment on cloud environments, it is beneficial to provide the
launcher options via environment variables instead of command line
arguments. This change supports reading options either from command line
or environment variable.

The `withEnvironment` method is a newly introduced helper method which
is useful when certain code should be executed in a context that exports
a set of environment variables.
commits.commitSubject: make launcher options configurable via env

more than just the NeonBeeConfig is needed to be configured.

feat: add support for custom error handlers

- rename ErrorHandler to DefaultErrorHandler
- remove create() pattern from the handler, because the
DefaultErrorHandler is a class and not an interface like the
ErrorHandler in Vert.x
- As in Vert.x an ErrorHandler interface already exists, reuse this
interface when implementing our own error handler.
- add errorHandler property to the ServerVerticleConfig

commits.message:
chore: add PMD rules to avoid unnecessary modifiers in tests

JUnit5 is more tolerant regarding the visibilities of Test classes and
methods than JUnit4, which required everything to be public. JUnit5
supports default package, public and protected visibility, even if it is
recommended to use the default package visibility, which improves the
readability of code.

These rules enforce the recommended standard.

Co-authored-by: Pascal Krause <pascal.krause@sap.com>
commits.commitSubject: add PMD rules to avoid unnecessary modifiers in tests

readability of code.

These rules enforce the recommended standard.

Co-authored-by: Pascal Krause <pascal.krause@sap.com>

commits.message:
refactor: simplify EntityProcessor

This patch ...

... simplifies the EntityProcessor by replacing ambiguous method names
and logic.

... removes the EntityProcessorTest, because all the tests are already
part of ODataUpdateEntityTest, ODataCreateEntityTest,
ODataDeleteEntityTest and ODataReadEntityTest.

... improves error handling in ODataEndpointHandler, by setting the
correct status code in case that the error is of type
ODataApplicationException.
commits.commitBody:
This patch ...

commits.message:
ci: use custom GitHub token for protected branches

In the push step, a custom github token should be used, because the
token which will be automatically generated by GitHub actions has not
sufficient authorization scopes to push to the protected main branch.

The custom token must be added to repository secrets.

commits.message:
fix: prevent UnsupportedOperationException when deploying NeonBeeModules

All model maps are stored in an unmodifiable map to ensure immutability.
When a NeonBeeModule is deployed at runtime, additional models are
registered in this map, which causes an UnsupportedOperationException.
The same occurs during deregistration of module undeployment.

To avoid this exception, the unmodifiable map will be copied, changed
and converted back to an unmodifiable map.
commits.commitBody:

commits.message:
fix: Broken HTTP status code propagation in ODataEndpointHandler

If the error code of an exception is in the range from 100 to 999, the
ErrorHandler is responsible for setting the HTTP status code. Setting
the status code to -1 signals the ErrorHandler that it must set a
proper status code, based on the passed exception.

This logic was broken, because in Vert.x 4.0 the behavior of failing a
routing context has changed. The new default status code has changed
from -1 to 500.
commits.commitSubject: Broken HTTP status code propagation in ODataEndpointHandler

commits.message:
fix: All static code errors

Due to an issue with the previous version of errorprone it was updated
to the latest version. With that new static code check errors appeared.
Thus all static code check tools have been updated and all static code
vilations have been resolved. For the rulesets deprecated rules have
been removed or replaced by their suggested alternatives.

With this change the minimum severity of the violations plugin was
decreased to INFO level, thus requiring contributors to acknowlege or
fix every violation found.

commits.message:
refactor: Remove broadcasting from DataRequest/simplify
LoggerManagerVerticle

See NeonBee/architecture/#18. In a recent change a "broadcasting" option
was added to DataRequest and DataVerticle, mainly to publish messages to
every listening verticle on the eventbus. The reason this was added was
due to a newly introduced "LoggerManagerVerticle", a DataVerticle to
maintain the levels of loggers. In order to be able to change the log
levels of all loggers in a clustered NeonBee instance at once, the
broadcasting option could be used to set the log levels to all cluster
nodes.

The introduction of the broadcasting option however, caused multiple
breaks in the concept of inter DataVerticle communication: With the
broadcasting parameter of DataRequest in place any interface methods
exposed in DataSource and DataSink will, in an undocumented manner, not
function as expected:

For DataSource any data returned by the called verticle will simply end
up in void. The called verticle does NOT know about this and thus will
not be able to react accordingly. Even worse, even the calling verticle
has no information whether and which verticles received the boadcsting
request, thus rendering the full interface useless in my opinion. For
DataSink similarely, the broadcasting event can not be tracked by the
calling verticle and a success / failure cannot be reported by by the
called verticle either.

As this option is rather limited in use and will cause side-effects
easily, it was decided in issue #18 to remove the parameter, to maybe be
reintroduced later with a better concept. This however requried to
re-implement parts of the mentioned LoggerManagerVerticle:

It was decided, that instead of using the DataVerticle implementation of
the LoggerManagerVerticle to handle the distribution of the logger
level, the LoggerManagerVerticle will be reduced to a pure JSON-based
DataVerticle which will publish a EventBus message to all cluster nodes
applying a LoggerConfiguration object.

Before this change LoggerConfiguration was much like a POJO with three
values: the logger name, a configuration level and an effective level.
The effective level however, unlike the name suggests, was not the
effective level of the underlying logger, but could have been "null" or
even a different value than the "real" effective logger value. This was
confusing. To overcome this, LoggerConfiguration was changed to
represent only the logger name and a configuration level. The change can
then be applied to the logger by calling a new "applyConfiguredLevel"
method, which will set the effective level. Also calling the
set/getEffectiveLevel methods will now really retrieve or set the level
of the associated logger, instead of just storing another value. This
again simplified the LoggerManagerVerticle implementation.

Last, it was decided to remove the LoggerConfigurations class, which was
previously used for inter-verticle communcation. Instead of using the
LoggerConfigurations class a default List / JsonArray was used, which
should allow for the LoggerManagerVerticle to be more easily used in an
upcoming admin UI implementation for NeonBee. This again reduced the
amount of testable code in NeonBee.
commits.commitBody:
LoggerManagerVerticle

commits.message:
refactor: simplify the EntityCollectionProcessor

This patch ...

- ... renames getEntities(...) to applyFilterQueryOption(...) because
getEntities(...) was misleading and inconsistent.

- ... removes isDebugEnabled(), because nothing was computed inside.

- ... changes all apply...QueryOption method signatures to throw an
error instead of failing the passed processPromise. This is required,
because if the processPromise has been failed the processing of the
request must be stopped.

- ... removes the count logic from readEntityCollection(...), because it
will be processed in countEntityCollection(...).

- ... removes applySelectQueryOption(...), because it only builds a
select list which should be done at a more central place. This change is
also a prerequisite for the expand query option, which also needs to
modify the select list.

- ... simplifies the countEntityCollection(...) method dramatically.

- ... rename EntityCollectionProcessor into
CountEntityCollectionProcessor, because we implement the
CountEntityCollectionProcessor interface.
commits.commitBody:

commits.message:
refactor: expose SLF4J Logger interface in LoggingFacade

Similar to other examples in NeonBee, NeonBee is trying to make the best
/ state of the art choice, when it comes to be choosing certain
underlying frameworks. When it comes to a logging facade and backend,
SLF4J / Logback was chosen by NeonBee. Previously NeonBee had its own
implementation for the LoggingFacade, possibly making wrong assumtions
when converting arguments into an array before passing it down to the
masqueraded logger.

This change reduces the logging facade to be making as less as possible
assumptions and clearly indicating that the underlying logger follows
the SLF4J rules, by exposing its interface. The JavaDoc was changed to
indicate that masquarading the logger will loose its ability to deal
with markers, also indicated by a UnsupportedOperationExeption thrown
when anyways trying.

As with the pre Vert.x 4 implementation the Vert.x logger did in fact
reorder arguments before forwarding it to the underlying logger
implementation, the plain SLF4J logger and LoggingFacade is no longer
reording arguments. Thus also NeonBee has to follow the SLF4J convention
[1] of putting the throwable as a last parameter into the format list.
This change adapts all calls to any longer.

[1] http://www.slf4j.org/faq.html#paramException
commits.commitSubject: expose SLF4J Logger interface in LoggingFacade

commits.message:
docs: Add CONTRIBUTING.md

Following the convention of many other open source projects, including Vert.x a CONTRIBUTING.md describes the process contributing to our open source project. The guide should clarify how to interact with out project.

As a template the UI5 Tooling [1] CONTRIBUTING.md was taken as a reference. As another open source SAP library, they provided already some good recommendations how processes can be treated, like signing off contributions with the CLA assistant (which still needs to be set-up).

RFCs for now are moved into the "/docs" folder. We may think of splitting this to a separate repository again in future.

[1] https://github.com/SAP/ui5-tooling/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md

commits.messageBody:
Following the convention of many other open source projects, including Vert.x a CONTRIBUTING.md describes the process contributing to our open source project. The guide should clarify how to interact with out project.

As a template the UI5 Tooling [1] CONTRIBUTING.md was taken as a reference. As another open source SAP library, they provided already some good recommendations how processes can be treated, like signing off contributions with the CLA assistant (which still needs to be set-up).

RFCs for now are moved into the "/docs" folder. We may think of splitting this to a separate repository again in future.

[1] https://github.com/SAP/ui5-tooling/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
commits.messageTitle: docs: Add CONTRIBUTING.md

commits.message:
docs: Add high-level milestones to docs/roadmap.md

After a brainstorming session with all contributors, ideas and features which have been previously often discussed and requested, have been collected. A new file structure under docs/roadmap.md and docs/milestones/*.md was introduced explaining future milestones in NeonBee and making future usage scnearios more predictable. Also contributors will more easily find a high level description of the feature added and the milestone structure can be used documenting and addressing further accepted ideas in future. This helps putting them on a timeline so others may account for when to expect these kinds of functionallity.

In contrast to RFCs the milestone structure is more focused on project management, features, timeline, etc. and not so much on the actual technical implementation details.

The section about data verticles was re-written and extended with an own document describing how dataflow is handled in NeonBee.

Two new roadmap items were added.

commits.message:
chore: Rename repository to just "neonbee"

Suggestion to rename the "neonbee-core" Git repository to just "neonbee"
for multiple reasons:

- NeonBee Core can be considered not just a component, thus the root
name fits better
- Choosing neonbee instead of neonbee-core as the main repository name,
allows people to find the main repository more easily
- It is in compliance to Vert.x where the vertx-core repository is
simply called "vert.x"
- The folder structure will be more clear in future as "neonbee" will be
on top of all it's components "neonbee-xxx".

commits.message:
test: Fix all failing unit tests on Windows

Ironed out some platform specific unit test failures on Windows, namely:

- Dates in windows come with a 6+ sub-nano second precission, regex was
adjusted
- The verifyHostIp test cannot change the env. variables on Windows and
was thus disabled
- TrackingDataHandlingStrategy had side effects as it was defined as a
field in the test
- Made the JobVerticleTest more forgiving, as on windows soemtimes
(depending on the CPU utilization) it only managed to execute 18 times,
even if 20 would have been possible given the time frame
- A lot of fixes for file system operations by introducing short delays.
In Windows file handles are closed asynchronously. Which means even if
Vert.x reports the write / delete operation is done, a subsequent
operation might fail, due to the file handles still beeing open.
Similarely for the WatchVerticle, an operation might be recorded with a
slight delay, which messed up the tests.
- Encoding issue with Gralde on Windows for EXPECTED_ENTITY_DATA_4
commits.commitSubject: Fix all failing unit tests on Windows

commits.message:
build(deps): downgrade `jackson` from 2.12.0 to 2.11.3

As Vert.x 4 seems to be compiled against jackson 2.11, the dependency
must be downgraded, because when using jackson 2.12 some methods cannot
be found and produce errors.

commits.message:
build: Move most .gradle files to /gradle and restructure
dependencies.gradle

To have a more clean root folder structure moving all .gradle plugin
files (except settings and build.gradle) to /gradle.

Also merged the dependencies.gralde into the build.gralde file, as this
is where most people would expect the dependencies definition. With that
also introduced a small change to the structure of our dependencies
definition:

Previously there was a big list of variables defining the versions of
the dependencies at the top of the dependencies definition. This made it
very hard to determine which specific dependency was meant, because the
variables where for instance named "jsonassert_version", for the
org.skyscreamer.jsonassert dependency. This made it very hard to follow,
which dependencies are being referenced. In order to simplify that, the
variables have been moved into the blocks where the dependencies are
defined and also only variables are used, if multiple dependencies
should always be referenced in the same version. For single dependencies
the version is now directly defined in the respective dependency
statement.
commits.commitSubject: Move most .gradle files to /gradle and restructure

commits.message:
build: remove unnecessary repositories from Gradle files and bump Gradle

Removing mavenLocal and gradlePluginPortal from repositories declaration
and removing pluginManagement / repositories block in settings.gradle
entirely.

Removing mavenLocal reduces the risk of local-only failure, due to some
leftover / old / locally built build depenencies for Vert.x or any other
of the used dependencies. Often times it would be next to impossible to
locate issues with a contributors failing local build, if mavenLocal
stays in the configuration. If local references are required for
testing, contributors should be inclined adding mavenLocal to the
repositories block themselfs.

Having gradlePluginPortal in the repositories block makes no sense, as
plugins are anyways loaded via the pluginManagement directive. After
removing mavenLocal from the pluginManagement / repositories section,
the leftover gradlePluginPortal section there is considered the default
setting in Gradle and thus the whole block could be removed.
commits.commitSubject: remove unnecessary repositories from Gradle files and bump Gradle

commits.message:
build: add required configuration for publishing to maven central

This patch ...

* ... adds meta information for license, scm or developers to the
pom.xml which is required by maven central.

* adds a task to create a test Javadoc artifact, which is required by
maven central.

* adds fixes for violations in the test Javadoc

* adds the script 'publishToMaven.sh' which can be used to add required
credentials when publishing to maven central.
commits.commitSubject: add required configuration for publishing to maven central
